content:
Hi Helen,

You must re-set your password with your e-mail service provider (Gmail), then use the new password in Thunderbird.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Have you thought of doing it directly server to server via webmail? https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/office/turn-on-automatic-forwarding-in-outlook-7f2670a1-7fff-4475-8a3c-5822d63b0c8e#picktab=web

Then your gmail imap account would synch with server and download everything.

In Thunderbird When you right click on highlighted emails and use 'Copy-to' gmail Inbox, that is uploading to gmail server via imap.

Gmail have limits on uploading via imap. https://support.google.com/a/answer/1071518?hl=en

If you have an Anti-Virus scanning everything then it can take forever as it scans everything being downloaded/uploaded and also every file that gets opened. Sometimes things seem to drop out. Hence advise on using 'Copy -to' and not 'Move-to' as that second option may delete emails off the original server - if something goes wrong and you use 'Copy-to' at least you can repeate the action. Suggestion - Access Anti-Virus and set up an exclusion to not scan anything in your Thunderbird profile folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova invece a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
Similar to what you've tried, this is how I've always done it (Windows). It preserves your whole existing setup.

1. Copy TB files from the old PC

- launch TB on the old PC

- go to TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

- the profile folder will open

- navigate three levels up to the AppData\Roaming folder

- close TB

- copy the AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird folder to a flash drive

2. Install and launch TB on the new PC, then start setting up the new profile. Skip to the next section if you've already installed TB and created a profile.

- on the 'Set Up Your Existing Email Address' screen, enter name and email address only

- click the 'Configure manually' link

- scroll down and click 'Cancel'

- exit setup

- close TB

3. Paste the copied TB files to the new PC

- open the AppData\Roaming folder like you did above

- delete the Thunderbird folder, or copy it somewhere if you want to save it

- replace it with the Thunderbird folder from the flash drive

- launch TB
creator: siffemoz

content: Those options are either services provided by your email provider, or software anti-spam that you have installed yourself. For specific, continual, spam from known addresses, setting up a filter may help. This URL has more info on using Thunderbird spam filter: https://blog.thunderbird.net/2024/09/thunderbird-and-spam/ personally, i use Mailwasher. it's free for one account and does an admirable job.
creator: davidsk

content: Thunderbird does not have a 'black list', one where emails are sent to spam in the future after having been marked once as smap. Thunderbird is willing to consider that spam once is not spam forever. This URL provides more information: https://blog.thunderbird.net/2024/09/thunderbird-and-spam/
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you for your reply. But in which case, why mark the email as Junk, if it's only to put it in the Junk folder and has no other purpose? Might as well delete straight away? Or am I missing something?

content: Well, that's your choice. You can set that in the global settings for spam. My personal preference is to set to leave for a few days and then delete. That gives me time to see the spam, as there have been a few times when such mail was important.

content: avevo usato mail redirect, ma le tue parole mi hanno acceso una lampadina: sono andato a verificare nei filtri ed ho trovato attivo proprio quel reindirizzamento, che ho subito provveduto ad eliminare. adesso proverò a monitorare la situazione, ma forse proprio grazie a te ho risolto! per il momento ti ringrazio, perché adoro Thunderbird e sono felice di essere fra il 3% degli utenti che, ogni tanto, sostiene anche economicamente il progetto! a mio parere non esite programma di posta elettronica migliore del nostro, mi sarebbe davvero dispiaciuto moltissimo doverlo abbandonare... resta però una domanda, a questo punto valida solo come curiosità: ma perché quel filtro continuava ad inoltrare, a 10 messaggi per volta, mail vecchie di più di un anno? in ogni caso ancora grazie e buona giornata
creator: grg0401

content:
grg0401 ha detto
resta però una domanda, a questo punto valida solo come curiosità: ma perché quel filtro continuava ad inoltrare, a 10 messaggi per volta, mail vecchie di più di un anno?

Difficile dirlo, bisognerebbe sapere come l'estensione ha costruito il filtro. I filtri di Thunderbird sono molto potenti e possono fare cose davvero notevoli; ad esempio possono attivarsi in base al mittente o in base al destinatario. Possono applicarsi al momento della ricezione della posta o ad intervalli di tempo stabilito o ancora manualmente. Possono applicarsi a tutta la posta di un account o solo ai messaggi spostai in una cartella... Insomma le possibilità sono veramente molte.
creator: @next

content: You don't have any conditions in the filter. You need to set a condition that will always be true.

content: Yes, if that is always true. Another possibility would be to set To as NOT equal to santaclaus That is, you want a filter that will always always be true.

content: Your original filter is correct: Match All Messages means to apply the filter without any criteria (conditions). Perhaps you're expecting the filter to run automatically, but this happens only for the Inbox. Filters must be run manually on other folders.

content: older versions are always available at https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/ just pick the release, the OS, the language and you're good to go. However, you may be better served if you share some of the details. If it's threading you do not like, that can be easily remedied. But, I respect some users prefer older versions. They still work, but, with a little customizing on your part, I think you will prefer the newer releases.
creator: davidsk

content:
David did not say how to remove threading, but following his encouragement that it could be done, I think I found the answer to turning off the threading in Thunderbird 128. 1. Went to "Settings" 2. In the section "Open messages in" I changed the selection from "a new tab" to "an existing message window.

So far after the above change, my Thunderbird 128 acts like my old Thunderbird 60 in that threading is not displayed. And now when I click on the X to close an email it just closes the email and not all of Thunderbird like it used to.
creator: jim435

content: Control Panel wouldn't be expected to find TB. To make a shortcut, open Win Explorer and navigate to C:\Program Files\Mozilla Thunderbird. R. click Thunderbird.exe > Copy. Go back to the desktop > R. click > Paste shortcut. Press F2 to rename it ( remove the .exe - Shortcut part).
creator: siffemoz
